Current Status Erik Wilde (@dret): Findings Summary and Assessment Draft

(6) API Landscape

  • Robust starter set of foundational APIs
    • Based on the capabilities and models of back-end systems
    • Gap between business-level capabilities and back-end APIs
  • Growing pains of centralized API team
    • Good starting point to build an API landscape foundation
    • API capabilities and culture remain inside team


Current Status Erik Wilde (@dret): Findings Summary and Assessment Draft

(7) API Layers: Model



Current Status Erik Wilde (@dret): Findings Summary and Assessment Draft

(8) API Layers: Example



Current Status Erik Wilde (@dret): Findings Summary and Assessment Draft

(9) Outside-In APIs

  • The current API landscape is based on inside-out APIs
    • API selection and design are based on internal systems
  • Outside-in APIs are representing business needs
    • Details of internal systems are hidden by the API
    • API selection and design are based on consumer needs
  • The planned capability catalog may be a good starting point
    • Requested capabilities are turned into API designs
    • APIs make capabilities (more) easily reusable

(11) Hype Cycle



Roadmap Erik Wilde (@dret): Findings Summary and Assessment Draft

(12) Where you are: In the API Trough

  • The API trough of disillusionment
    • The major API benefit is not through their technologies
    • Centralizing API practices defeats their fundamental purpose
  • Realizing the main benefits takes more than technology
    • Main API benefit #1: More focus on business through outside-in APIs
    • Main API benefit #2: Faster time-to-market through self-contained implementations
  • API enlightenment takes time and resources
    • API practices must be decentralized (API first)
    • Everybody must understand and embrace the API journey
    • Picking quick wins can serve as helpful validation


Roadmap Erik Wilde (@dret): Findings Summary and Assessment Draft

(13) Where you will be: Two Scenarios

  1. This API thing really doesn't work for us
    • APIs still may make sense as thin wrappers around technical assets
    • Adjust expectations accordingly
  2. API value mostly is in plumbing for digital transformation
    • Good starting point with a set of existing system APIs
    • Establish an API program to establish APIs in the organization
    • Culture and organization are the hardest issues to address
    • Tooling can be adjusted as necessary along the way


Recommendations

Outline (Recommendations)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. Current Status [4]
  3. Roadmap [3]

Recommendations Erik Wilde (@dret): Findings Summary and Assessment Draft

(15) Why do you use APIs?

  • Opening back-end systems (inside-out) is one possible goal
  • Faster delivery of solutions is another possible goal
  • Centralized API competence/development has fundamental limitations


Recommendations Erik Wilde (@dret): Findings Summary and Assessment Draft

(16) Centralization Bottleneck

  • APIs work best as ecosystems that result in rich and evolving landscapes
  • Centralization is a good first step towards decentralization
  • Setting up a Center for Enablement (C4E) for API practices
  • Start small with a set of capabilities exposed as well-designed APIs
    • Demand management as consolidator of requested capabilities
    • Starting to enable other teams to contribute to the API landscape


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. Current Status [4]

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Findings Summary and Assessment Draft

(18) To API or not to API

  • APIs help to disentangle complicated IT systems
  • APIs provide a path to (possibly complex) IT ecosystems
  • API success needs a strategy and a program
  • Entel's current position is not atypical in API journeys


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Findings Summary and Assessment Draft
